Question text: \text{Which of the following languages are decidable?}
\text{For which of the following languages does there exist a } v ∈ Σ^{*}\text{ such that they are decidable?}
Explanations: The condition does not depend on w.
Choose v as the encoding of a TM that never halts.

Question text: \text{Let }L ⊆ Σ* \text{be finite. Which of the following languages are semi-decidable?}
Explanations: We can check Mw[x]↓ for each x ∈ L.

Question text: \text{Is there a regular language }L ∈ NP?
Explanations: In fact, all regular languages are in NP.

Question text: \text{For the NP-complete problem SAT, which of the following variants of SAT are NP-complete, assuming} P \neq NP?
AnswerOptions: \text{Each variable} x_{i} \text{occurs only once in F.}
Explanations: The formula is always satisfied if all variables are true.
One can write x ∧ y as ¬(¬x ∨ ¬y).

As long as possible, replace ¬(x ∧ y) with ¬x ∨ ¬y, ¬(x ∨ y) with ¬x ∧ ¬y, and ¬¬x with x. Afterward, each variable is still used only once, and negations can only occur directly before variables. If ¬x is contained, set x to false, otherwise to true. This is always a satisfying assignment.

Question text: \text{Which of the following languages are decidable?}
\text{Which of the following statements are true?}
AnswerOptions: \text{Let }L1 ⊆ Σ^* \text{ be decidable, and }L2 ⊆ Σ* \text{ be undecidable. Then } L1 ∪ L2 \text{ is undecidable.}
\text{ Let } L1, L2 ⊆ Σ* \text{ be decidable languages. Then }L1 ∖ L2 \text{ is decidable.}
\text{ Let }L1 ⊆ Σ* \text{ be decidable, and }L2 ⊆ Σ* \text{ be semi-decidable. Then there exists a } w ∈ Σ^{*} \text{such that }M_{w} \text{ decides the language }L1 ∩ L2.

Question text: \text{Which of the following statements are true?}
AnswerOptions: \text{ For every } v ∈ Σ^{*}, L_v := \{w ∈ Σ*: ww ∈ L(M_{v})\} \text{ is semi-decidable.}
\text{ For every } v ∈ Σ^{*}, L_{v} := \{w ∈ Σ*: L(Mw) ≠ L(Mv)\} \text{ is semi-decidable.}
\text{ For every } v ∈ Σ^{*}, L_{v} := {w ∈ Σ*: w ∉ L(Mv)} \text{ is semi-decidable. }
Explanations: With L(Mv) = Σ*, these are the non-terminating TMs, see Corollary 5.51.

Question text: \text{For the NP-complete problem SAT, which of the following variants of SAT are NP-complete, assuming } P \neq NP?
AnswerOptions: \text{The formula F is in conjunctive normal form, i.e., it has the form } F1 ∧ … ∧ Fm, \text{ where each Fi has the form } y_1 ∨ … ∨ y_i\text{ and }  y_1, …, y_i \text{ are literals.}
\text{ The formula F contains each variable x_{i} at most 2022 times.}
\text{The formula F is in disjunctive normal form, i.e., it has the form }F_1 ∨ … ∨ F_m,\text{ where each Fi has the form }y_1 ∧ … ∧ y_i \text{ and }y_1, …, y_i\text{ are literals.}
Explanations: For a variable x that occurs more frequently, every second occurrence is replaced by the new variable x', and we consider the new formula F ∧ (¬x ∨ x') ∧ (¬x' ∨ x). We repeat this until the condition is met.
F is satisfiable if one of the Fi is. The latter can be easily verified.

Question text: \text{Let }\{M := {L ⊆ Σ^{*}: L ≤_{p} SAT\}\text{ be the set of languages that can be reduced to SAT in polynomial time. Which of the following statements are true?}
AnswerOptions: If P \neq NP, \text{ then there exists a language } L ∈ M \text{ that cannot be decided by any Turing machine in polynomial time.}
\text{ Every problem in M can be decided by a non-deterministic Turing machine in polynomial time. }
All NP-complete problems are in M.

Question text: \text{Let } f: \Sigma^{*} \rightarrow \Sigma^{*} \text{ be a computable, partial function. The graph of  f  is the set} \{(w, f(w)) | w \in \Sigma^{*}, f(w) \neq \perp\}.
Explanations: \text{When building a TM that calculates f(w) we run into the halting problem,we never know if its part or not}
\text{this implies we can check if a word isnt in it.}
\text{Given word w: we can simply calculate f(w) and get confirmation.}

Question text: \text{Let } \Sigma := \{a, b\} \text{ and let L} \subseteq \Sigma^{*}. \text{Which of the following statements are true?}
AnswerOptions: \text{ If } L \in NP, \text{ then } L^{a} \in NP.
Explanations: This statement is not necessarily true.
If L^{a} \in NP \text{ and } L^{b} \in NP, \text{then} L \in NP.

Question text: \text{Let } \Sigma \text{ be an alphabet. Let } \mathcal{K} \text{ be the set of all context-free grammars with terminals from } \Sigma.\text{ Given a language }L \subseteq \Sigma^{*}, let \min(L)\text{ be the set of shortest words in L. Which of the following sets are decidable?}
Explanations: \text{This splits down to finding the smallest word of a grammar }G_1 \text{and then checking if its in }G_2 \text{we know that we can check with CYK if w is contained,and the smallest word can be computed by going through its automaton.}
\text{we cannot decide equality for context free languages.}
\text{we can compute if a Language is Empty, but we cant compute}L(G_1)\\ L(G_2)

Question text: \text{Let }A, B, C \text{be languages over the same alphabet} \Sigma.\text{Which of the following statements are true?}
AnswerOptions: A \leq_{p} B \text{ if and only if }A \leq_{p} B.
\text{ Let H be the (general) halting problem. If }A \in NP,\text{ then }A \leq_{p} H.
\text{A and B are decidable if and only if A \leq B and B \leq A.}
Explanations: If A \in NP, then A \leq_{p} H.
This statement is not necessarily true.

Question text: \text{Reminder: A family of languages is a set of sets. Choose all statements that apply. Note in particular that every decidable set is also semi-decidable.}
AnswerOptions: \text{There is a countably infinite family of decidable languages } \{L_{i}\} _{i=1}^{\infty} \text{ over the same alphabet, such that } \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} L_{i} \text{is not semi-decidable.}
\text{There is a countably infinite family of decidable languages } \{L_i\}_{i=1}^{\infty} \text{over the same alphabet, such that }\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} L_i \text{is undecidable.}
\text{There is a countably infinite family of decidable languages } \{L_i\}_{i=1}^{\infty} \text{over the same alphabet, such that }\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} L_i \text{is decidable.}

Question text: \text{Which of the following problems are decidable?}
AnswerOptions: \text{Given: A deterministic Turing machine  M  with input alphabet }\Sigma\text{ and  }n \in \mathbb{N} . \text{ Problem: Does  M  halt in } n \text{ steps for every arbitrary input } w \in \Sigma^{*} ?
\text{ Given: A deterministic Turing machine  M . Problem: Does  M  visit the start state at least twice with empty input?}
\text{ Given: A deterministic Turing machine  M  and } n \in \mathbb{N} . \text{ Problem: Is there a state such that  M  visits this state at least } n \text{ times with empty input? }
Explanations: Since only  n  characters can be read in  n  steps, only a finite number of words need to be checked.
In  |Q|n + 1  steps,  M  either visits a state at least twice or halts.

Question text: \text{Let }\Sigma := \{0, 1\}. \text{Which of the following languages are undecidable?}
Explanations: Simple reduction from the halting problem.
Simple reduction from the halting problem.
Simple reduction from the halting problem.

Question text: \text{Let }A, B, C \text{ be languages over the same alphabet }\Sigma. \text{ Which of the following statements are true?}
AnswerOptions: \text{Assume A is NP-complete and }\overline{A} \in \text{NP}.\text{ Then for all } B \in \text{NP}, \overline{B} \in \text{NP}.
Explanations: \text{Counterexample: Choose C as }\emptyset\text{then there is no garantie at all for } A ≤ B

Question text: \text{From which of the following statements would } P = NP \text{ follow?}
AnswerOptions: \text{For at least one problem in NP, there exists a polynomial time-bounded algorithm.}
Explanations: The problem would also need to be NP-complete.

Question text: \text{Let }\Sigma \text{ be an alphabet. Let }f: \mathcal{P}(\Sigma^{*}) \times \mathcal{P}(\Sigma^{*}) \rightarrow \mathcal{P}(\Sigma^{*}) \text{ be a function from pairs of languages to languages. Choose all statements that apply.}
AnswerOptions: \text{Assume }f(A, \overline{B}) \text{ is semi-decidable for all semi-decidable languages }A, B. \text{ Then }f(\overline{A}, B) \text{ is also semi-decidable for all semi-decidable languages }A, B.
\text{ Assume }f(A, B) \text{ is decidable for all semi-decidable languages A, B. Let A, B, C be semi-decidable. Then }f(A, f(B, C)) \text{ is decidable.}
\text{ Assume }f(A, \overline{B}) \text{ is semi-decidable for all decidable languages }A, B. \text{ Then }f(\overline{A}, B) \text{ is also semi-decidable for all decidable languages }A, B.

Question text: \text{Which of the following languages are decidable?}
\text{Let L be an arbitrary undecidable language and } a ∈ Σ. \text{Which of the following statements are true?}
AnswerOptions: \text{ There exists no TM M with }L(M) = L.
Explanations: If L were decidable, L would also be decidable due to closure properties.
If L is semi-decidable, there exists one.

Question text: \text{Let M be an arbitrary deterministic Turing machine such that there exists an input } w ∈ Σ^{*} \text{on which M makes infinitely many steps. Which statements are true}?
Explanations: \text{ Otherwise, M would halt on w. }
It can be, for example, L(M) = ∅.
L(M) \text{ is always semi-decidable. You simply input the word and see if it returns.}

Question text: \text{Which statements are true?}
AnswerOptions: \text{If } L ∈ P, \text{ then } L ∈ NP. \text{ Even } L ∈ P.
\text{ Every regular language is in NP. Even in P.}
\text{ Every context-free language is in P. The CYK algorithm needs cubic, i.e., polynomial time to decide the word problem for CFGs.}

Question text: Assume P ≠ NP. Let A, B ⊆ Σ* be arbitrary languages such that A ∈ NP and B is NP-complete. Which statements are true?
Explanations: This statement is not necessarily true.
This statement is not necessarily true.

Question text: \text{Let } L \text{ be a context-free language. Which statements are true?}
Explanations: This follows, for example, from the existence of CYK.

Question text: \text{Let } L_1, L_2 \subseteq \Sigma^{*} \text{be decidable languages. Which of the following languages are decidable?}
Explanations: For input  w , we go through all decompositions into two subwords.

Question text: \text{Let } L \subseteq \{0\}^{*}  \text{be undecidable. Which of the following functions } f: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N} \text{ are computable? }
\text{Let } A, B \subseteq \Sigma^{*} \text{ be languages with } A \leq_p \text{SAT} \leq_p B .\text{ Which statements are true?}
Explanations: \text{B might be even an even harder Problem: couterexample: H_0},...
\text{To obtain a reduction,simply reduce B to SAT and then to A}

Question text: \text{Let } L \subseteq \Sigma^{*} \{\#\} \Sigma^{*} \text{ be a language such that } L \in \text{P} ;  L \text{ thus contains words of the form }   u\#v ,\text{ with }   u, v \in \Sigma^{*} .\text{ Which of the following languages are in NP?}
Explanations: Counterexample  L := \{G\#w \mid G \text{ CFG} \wedge w \notin L(G)\} .
